awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of High-Throughput Fluorescence Imaging System for Undergraduate Research and Teaching at Pace University
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Pace University to acquire an automated high-resolution imaging system for screening large numbers of fluorescent zebrafish larvae and cancer cells. This automated imaging system will dramatically enhance scientific research at Pace University. Beyond being used by researchers at Pace University, the imaging system will also be integrated into the scientific training of undergraduate students enrolled in upper-division Biology and Chemistry courses. Students in these courses will gain hands-on research experiences and improve their quantitative and analytical skills as they work through the large datasets that they will collect. The use of the system in teaching laboratories will allow us to pursue inquiry-based projects within upper-level biology classes, exposing many more students to authentic scientific experimentation and discovery.  

The automated high-resolution fluorescence imaging system will be used to tackle a broad range of important questions from the fields of neuroscience, developmental biology, cancer biology, and biophysical chemistry. Furthermore, this imaging system will facilitate and promote interdepartmental research collaborations between the Biology and Chemistry departments, and engage undergraduates in publishable research. This imaging system will allow faculty and students to determine how various genes impact neural circuits, to identify key genes governing sensory organ development and regeneration, to examine cell proliferations, and to work on other topics. The results from the research obtained with this imaging system will be shared via scientific meetings and published in peer-reviewed journals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award allowed us to purchase an instrument that automates the microscopic imaging of zebrafish larvae, cultured cancer cells, and drug delivery particles, all of which can add to our understanding of basic biological mechanisms and potentially human disease and treatments in the future. There were several significant outcomes of this award, the first being that the equipment purchased with the award has contributed tremendously to the research infrastructure of our university and will continue to serve our research and teaching missions for years to come. We are now able to automate a tedious experimental task that was previously performed by undergraduate students, freeing those students up to focus on experimental design, data analysis, and other important aspects of biomedical research. In addition this award enabled us to train numerous students, many from populations historically underrepresented in STEM fields, in cutting edge research technology they would not otherwise have been able to access. Training in areas such as automation, microscopic imaging, and microfluidics has already helped launch several of these students' scientific careers, contributing to their admission to biomedical graduate programs. The instrument will continue to be used in coursework for new programs in Pharmaceutical Sciences and Chemical Biology as well, providing even more students with highly in-demand technical skills that will make them more competitive in the scientific job market.


Last Modified: 01/31/2024
Modified by: Aaron B Steiner
